intro: Cassebeeria hirtella, commonly known as the hairy cassia, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its pod-like fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as woodlands and grasslands. Its leaves are compound, with small, hairy leaflets that give it its common name. The flowers are yellow and attract pollinators like bees and butterflies.
